item.title: Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Players Spot Interesting Connection Between Citadelle Des Morts and Multiplayer
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Citadelle des Morts is set to arrive in Black Ops 6 on December 5.
  • A connection between the upcoming Zombies map and the multiplayer map may just be asset reuse.

A Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 player online has noticed an interesting connection between multiplayer and the upcoming Zombies map, Citadelle des Morts. The detail has sparked various Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Zombies theories online as a result.

Citadelle des Morts is the upcoming Call of Duty Zombies map in Black Ops 6 . The map is set to arrive on December 5, bringing a new Wonder Weapon into the game. Beyond this, little is known of what to expect when Citedelle des Morts drops. Presumably, it will have another complex Easter egg to solve, which is how a lot of the underlying Call of Duty Zombies backstory is told nowadays. Hopefully, it also comes with a new special enemy to help keep things feeling fresh on the battlefield.

Redditor Main_Health_1670 noticed that the new Season 1 Black Ops 6 map, Hideout, appears in a picture at the start of the Citadelle des Morts trailer. Comparing the two side by side, it's very clearly Hideout. The user also noticed that around the map, there are various notes with references to Avalon, the city-state where Citadelle des Morts is set. This led many in the thread to ponder about whether this is just a coincidence, or whether it has any real relevance to Call of Duty Zombies.

Citadelle des Morts May Have Connection to New Black Ops 6 Multiplayer Map

In the thread, it was largely agreed that this is more than likely just a classic case of asset reuse. The warehouse from Hideout looks generic enough that it could be from anywhere, and it makes sense to reuse the asset for the photograph rather than spending time and resources making a completely new area. However, the Call of Duty Zombies story is incredibly complex and has a history of small references meaning something important in the long run, so it's not impossible that the use of Hideout has a hidden meaning not yet understood. With Citedelle des Morts set to release on December 5, it's not long until players find out.

With Citadelle des Morts and beyond, Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 players have plenty to look forward to in the coming months. A recent leak also revealed that a classic game mode may be coming to Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 , although nothing has been officially confirmed at this point. Hopefully, Season 1 Reloaded will come with even more maps for players to enjoy online when it drops.

item.title: Overwatch 2's Hazard is Already Getting Neat Fan-Made Skin Concepts
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Overwatch 2 fans are already making skin concepts for Hazard, introducing fun ideas for the hero.
  • Two standout concepts transform the tank into Ben 10's Diamondback and a vampire.
  • Hazard, the new Overwatch 2 hero, will join the game as a tank in Season 14, expanding the game's hero roster.

Overwatch 2 fans have made skin concepts for Hazard and shared the creative results online. The cast of Overwatch 2 is made up of veteran heroes from the first game as well as a new generation of characters that has been introduced throughout the sequel's life cycle. And soon, this list will grow with the arrival of yet another new face.

Hazard is the new Overwatch 2 hero who will be added to the shooter with the arrival of Season 14. Leader of the Phreaks, a group of rebels with whom he formed a deep bond after being helped by them, Hazard is also Overwatch 2 's new playable tank, offering a new pick for players to take to the front line in matches. The new character is not yet available in Blizzard's shooter, but that hasn't stopped some community members from exercising their imagination and creating cosmetic concepts for him.

Two Overwatch 2 fans have created impressive skin concepts for Hazard, one turning the hero into Diamondhead from Ben 10 . Created by Redditor Onframer, the artwork gives the tank the same design as the alien from the popular Cartoon Network animation, with a green body and black and white outfit. Meanwhile, the artist, who has already shared other creative Overwatch 2 skin concepts, has kept some traits from Hazard's original design; the style of the spikes on his back, the shotgun the hero carries on his right arm, and the scythe he has equipped on his left arm.

Hazard Isn't Out Yet But Already Has Skin Concepts Created By Overwatch 2 Fans

The second skin concept was created by Redditor Time_Huckleberry4125, and this time it turns Hazard into a vampire. While the Overwatch 2 fan art retains his weapons and physique, the tank got a makeover with an eye-catching red outfit and a cross on his chest. The comments section noted that the OP's fan art is also reminiscent of a vampire hunter and that the outfit they created strongly reminds of those worn by the Belmont family from the Castlevania franchise.

Following the end of the testing period that the devs carried out in anticipation of Hazard's release, players are now waiting for his official debut in the hero shooter's fourteenth season. After this, Overwatch 2 's roster will increase to 42 playable heroes, with the leader of the Phreaks being the 13th tank to join the game's ranks. Players will soon discover how Hazard will fit into the Overwatch 2 meta and what official cosmetics the hero will get.

item.title: Batman: Arkham Shadow Deserves to Be a Layup for Camouflaj, Not an Alley-Oop for Rocksteady
item.description:
It’s difficult to know with certainty anymore whether a game will get a sequel as its commercial performance is often what determines that, even with bigger franchise IPs. Warner Bros. recently stated its gaming priorities, which would presumably be the most lucrative IPs with the highest success rates, and it’s no surprise that this statement acknowledges Batman in particular regarding DC; Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League was likely a low point for DC lately, not unlike how Marvel’s Avengers was a low point for Marvel, while Batman: Arkham Shadow has turned quite a few heads despite being exclusive to the Meta Quest 3/3S.

Batman: Arkham Shadow is a modern point of re-entry into the Arkhamverse’s beloved continuity long before Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League takes place and could give Rocksteady an opportunity to follow the Meta Quest 3 exclusive with a direct sequel that stars Roger Craig Smith as Batman and returns to the standard third-person perspective. That said, Rocksteady would be better equipped to work on a direct sequel to Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League and start a new chapter in the Arkhamverse while allowing Camouflaj to develop its own direct sequel in the Arkhamverse’s prequel era.

A Batman: Arkham Shadow Sequel Would Be in No Better Hands Than Camouflaj’s

Camouflaj has been fairly plain lately with how viable the opportunity may be for it to develop its own sequel to Batman: Arkham Shadow and no studio would be more deserving. Indeed, the trail of breadcrumbs Shadow lays out already foreshadows a sequel that would presumably feature Poison Ivy’s origin story, at least given how many times Dr. Pamela Isley is referred to with relevance to the game’s narrative events, teasing how imminent her transformation may be in the canon timeline.

Likewise, Dr. Harleen Quinzel, Dr. Jonathan Crane, and District Attorney Harvey Dent are all on the cusp of becoming colorful super-criminals Harley Quinn, Scarecrow, and Two-Face, and it’d be fantastic to see or all of them reprised by Tara Strong, Elijah Wood, and Troy Baker respectively.

Otherwise, the sequel could take a much-needed break from these iconic characters and, as Shadow did, emphasize even more lesser-known or underdeveloped antagonists. Regardless, the Arkhamverse is in wholly competent hands at Camouflaj, and a direct sequel taking place not long after Shadow should be its own to pursue.

Rocksteady Has a Responsibility to Give the Arkhamverse a New Modern Era

Because it developed three excellent entries in the Arkhamverse and conceived the franchise’s lore-rich continuity in the first place, it’s only natural to want Rocksteady back at the helm of Batman-led games. It’s odd, though, that a decade ago Rocksteady was believably content to let Gotham City and its Batman smolder to ashes. Rocksteady getting back into the saddle for Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League wasn’t even seen as a willingness for the studio to continue making Arkham games because of how much the live-service shooter has cleaved itself away from them.

The needless retcons and strange narrative choices it makes include an arguably jarring reinterpretation of Harley Quinn and a complete character swap for Deadshot, both of which Rocksteady poorly explains away. Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League didn’t even keep the Justice League dead and hold to its convictions for the game’s core conceit; introducing a multiverse was always going to muddy the Arkhamverse’s clear waters, but now there are a lot of questions that need answering and Rocksteady’s never been one to divulge all of its narrative loopholes and secrets.

Nonetheless, if Batman is going to become its focus once more due to the Arkham games being as popular as they are, Rocksteady has an obligation to forge a path forward for the Arkhamverse in the present day. A Batman story in the Arkhamverse after he’s been part of the Justice League could be enthralling now that his connections to other corners of the DC mythology are broadened, and it wouldn’t be out of the realm of possibility anymore to hear voice messages from characters such as Diana Prince or Clark Kent addressed to Bruce Wayne.

item.title: 8 Survival Games To Play If You Love Subnautica
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Vivid environments, immersive exploration, and chilling monsters make these games thrilling to play.
  • The Long Dark , Minecraft , and Valheim offer exploration, challenges, and unique environments similar to Subnautica .
  • From Grounded's unexpected thrills to Don't Starve's horror undertones, these games provide immersive and eerie survival experiences akin to Subnautica .

Subnautica is a survival exploration game with heavy horror undertones. Released in 2018 and developed by Unknown Worlds Entertainment, players find themselves stranded on an oceanic alien planet following a spaceship crash. To escape this strange planet, players must delve into its darkest depths to pursue knowledge and crafting materials. Be warned, giant monsters lurk in the gloom, and many of this planet's inhabitants are deadly.

From its beautifully varied environments to the isolating terror of its seabeds, there's a lot to love about Subnautica . The following games have been selected because they share such characteristics, whether in their features or atmospheres, and the emotions they evoke in players.

1 The Long Dark

Beauty, Isolation, Terror

The Long Dark is a realistic survival exploration game. In it, players find themselves trapped in the Canadian wilderness, where they must learn to live alongside Mother Nature or die trying.

Players who enjoyed journeying through the beautiful depths of Subnautica will find a lot to enjoy in this game. The Long Dark is teeming with breathtaking environments to explore, all with their own unique designs and chilling dangers. Death lurks around every corner, making exploration equal parts exhilarating and terrifying. Like Subnautica , The Long Dark is a game of isolation where players are left to explore an unfamiliar world.

2 Minecraft

Freedom & Variety

Needing no introduction for many, Minecraft is a blocky survival crafting game. With few concrete goals, players are given unprecedented freedom to find meaning and fun in this game, whether through building, mining, or fighting.

Like Subnautica , Minecraft presents players with a vast array of biomes to explore, each with unique resources, structures, and creatures. With enormous underground caverns, sprawling jungles, and fiery hellscapes, Minecraft will surely satisfy players who loved Subnautica for its environmental exploration. Minecraft also provides players with significant gameplay flexibility. Players are free to do whatever they want, whether that be exploration, base building, or boss hunting.

3 Valheim

Base Building & Linear Progression

Valheim is a survival exploration game inspired by Viking mythos. In it, players undertake the role of a dead warrior tasked with taming the fantastical realm of Valheim. Players must explore, craft, and build if they hope to be strong enough to slay the mythical beasts of this land.

With detailed and satisfying base building, players can build sprawling Viking strongholds and epic mead halls. Similar to Subnautica , Valheim also presents players with an array of biomes, all with unique challenges to overcome and materials to be rewarded with. Players must master one biome and use the resources gained from it to increase their power before taking on the next boss.

4 Terraria

Exploration & Threat

Terraria is a survival crafting game in which players find themselves in a fantastical world filled with a variety of monsters and environments. Players must dig deep, collect resources, and grow stronger so they can slay increasingly more challenging bosses.

Terraria presents a similar gameplay loop to that of Subnautica , where players explore and conquer new environments and are rewarded with new and more powerful materials. In an instant, exploration of these environs can go from peaceful to a battle for life and death; doubly so if a boss spawns unexpectedly.

5 Fallout 4

The Freedom to Explore a Familiar Land Ravished by Time and War

Fallout 4 is a post-apocalyptic open-world RPG where players take on the role of a vault dweller, a person sheltered for hundreds of years from the nuclear fallout that has ravaged the world. Explore a wasteland whose people, politics, and wildlife have been mutated by hundreds of years of radiation exposure.

Like Subnautica , Fallout 4 allows players to explore an eerily familiar alien world through the eyes of a character just as poorly adjusted as themselves. The wastelands of Fallout 4 are also filled with alien creatures with unique appearances, behaviors, and environments. Some of them are even human, or at least used to be.

6 Grounded

Linear Progression & Unexpected Thrills

Grounded is a survival crafting game where players play as a child who has been shrunk to the size of an ant as they struggle to live in a garden. Like all gardens, this one is teeming with insects, from giant spiders to blood-sucking mosquitoes. Players must explore, craft, and build to conquer the trials of this game.

Grounded shares a similar gameplay loop with Subnautica , where players explore new environs, collect materials, and become stronger, enabling them to take on more deadly opponents. Grounded is also a peaceful and wonder-filled game until it isn't. The game can change instantly, from thrilling exploration to terror-filled panic, as players are the prey of many bugs.

7 Don't Starve

Wonder, Fear, Horror

Don't Starve is a survival crafting game with distinct horror undertones and an unsettling atmosphere. Players must fight for survival in a semi-fantastical land devoid of human life. No matter how much players explore, collect resources, and build in this harsh world, death is inevitable.

Players who love Subnautica will thoroughly enjoy exploring the world of Don't Starve , a world that is equally wonderful and whimsical as it is terrifying and unsettling. In Don't Starve , exploration can go from calm to chilling in seconds. Whether it be monsters, sanity, or the darkness of caverns, players caught unprepared will quickly succumb to the dangers of the wilderness.

8 The Forest

Hostility & Claustrophobia

The Forest is a realistic survival horror game. The sole survivors of a plane crash, players must explore, craft, and fight their way to survival on a remote island filled with cannibals and humanoid mutants, all the while searching for a means to escape.

As in Subnautics , The Forest's story forces players to delve deep into claustrophobic depths. Death could be hiding around every twist of the cave, and the darkness hides some truly grotesque horrors, both living and dead. Exploration above ground sees players encounter beautiful and highly realistic environments. Peace and curiosity are, however, inevitably replaced by fear upon encountering cannibals or, even worse, mutants.

item.title: The Last of Us Would Be Remiss Not to Track Ghost of Yotei’s Footprints
item.description:
Ghost of Yotei was announced at the last State of Play after being one of the only PlayStation first-party studio games to not have any updates in a long spell. The inevitable announcement trailer didn’t disappoint, either, as it introduced a new protagonist, Atsu, in a new locale: the sequel’s eponymous Mount Yotei and its surrounding environs.

Other than featuring a protagonist who assumes a Ghost persona over 300 years after Jin Sakai had, nothing else seems to connect Ghost of Yotei and Ghost of Tsushima , at least from what little has been revealed so far. It’s unclear if this was always the intended direction for the IP, but Sucker Punch choosing to make this transition now for the sequel is remarkably clever and forward-thinking as the Ghost franchise can no longer be pigeonholed to a single, stagnant story or protagonist—a storytelling boon that The Last of Us would be wise to take heed of before it’s too late.

Ghost of Yotei Branching Out Extends the IP’s Shelf Life Astronomically

Ghost of Yotei may be reinventing the Ghost origin tale and enabling the Ghost franchise to become an anthological series that could be feasibly endless depending on how many new protagonists, settings, and eras it would like to spotlight. Jin and Atsu could only be two of countless Ghosts and the franchise would only need to end once Sucker Punch’s creativity for emotional samurai/ronin stories in breathtaking vistas runs dry.

Sucker Punch has probably learned a lot working on Tsushima and now gets to rewrite the book on its Ghost IP, reworking or adding to Yotei everything it wished it had for Tsushima . That process can be repeated with each new entry, engrossing players in its gorgeous Japanese settings but telling various stories and inheriting new gameplay mechanics to ensure that every installment has a signature stamp to distinguish them.

Jin was a great protagonist, but holding onto him dearly and forcing development out of him in a sequel could’ve diluted his character arc. Rather, Atsu can be a blank canvas and that’s immediately more enticing with virtually nothing known about her at the moment aside from what weapons she carries.

The Last of Us is Wilting While Anchored to Joel and Ellie

Naughty Dog’s biggest storytelling strength has always been its intimate character-driven stories and interactions, and as such it’s no surprise that The Last of Us has been fully enmeshed in the lives of Joel and Ellie.

It’s both a blessing and a curse that Naughty Dog characters or protagonists are written so well because it begs sequels to give them closure or continue their narratives; Joel dying in The Last of Us Part 2 is a testament to this, for example, as he has only been around for one other game and yet was adored enough to incite a gross reaction to his murder and the protagonist responsible for committing it. Now, a third game is almost guaranteed to follow Ellie once more and attempt to bookend her story.

Neil Druckmann confessing that there is “probably one more chapter” left to tell for The Last of Us seems needlessly limiting in a franchise that could tell endless fascinating stories of characters whose suffering and relationships with those around them are poignant against a terrifying post-apocalyptic backdrop. The Last of Us doesn’t need to warp its title like Ghost of Yotei is to renew itself.

Instead, all it needs to do is dedicate installments to stories about other characters and settings without anchoring the series to Joel and Ellie’s exploits. Ironically, The Last of Us ’ online multiplayer game might’ve finally been the outlet to do that before it was canceled and there’s no promise anymore of additional characters getting their time in the sun during or after The Last of Us Part 3 .
